Issues.Title: fix(bazel): add terser as an optional peer dependency
Issues.Body:
`ng_package` rule has an implicitly optional depedency on terser https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/a48573efe8eca12ccfbe0c11fb60f322387bf79a/packages/bazel/src/ng_package/ng_package.bzl#L36

When using this rule without terser being available we get the below error;
```
ERROR: /home/circleci/ng/modules/express-engine/BUILD.bazel:22:1: every rule of type ng_package implicitly depends upon the target '@npm//terser/bin:terser', but this target could not be found because of: no such package '@npm//terser/bin': BUILD file not found in directory 'terser/bin' of external repository @npm. Add a BUILD file to a directory to mark it as a package.
ERROR: Analysis of target '//modules/express-engine:npm_package' failed; build aborted: no such package '@npm//terser/bin': BUILD file not found in directory 'terser/bin' of external repository @npm. Add a BUILD file to a directory to mark it as a package.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(bazel): add terser as an optional peer dependency" (#33891)

Issues.Title: packaging of @angular/bazel changes esm5.bzl to a format that breaks buildifier_check
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/bazel ### Is this a regression? Yes this seems to be present in at least all of 8.2.x releases ### Description When I download @angular/bazel from npmjs.org at https://registry.npmjs.org/@angular/bazel/-/bazel-8.2.13.tgz I can see that the file src/esm5.bzl has a whitespace tab where some text is removed by the packager. This tab causes problems for the buildifier_check tool in bazel when I try to build So the original file has this https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/341d5847d6a7d3f922040f5baf11f7bc64e6f9bc/packages/bazel/src/esm5.bzl#L98 specifically: ``` elif replay_compiler_name.startswith("ngc-wrapped"): compiler = ctx.executable._ngc_wrapped # BEGIN-INTERNAL # If the "replay_compiler" path does not refer to "ngc_wrapped" from the "@npm" workspace, # we use "ngc_wrapped" from within the Angular workspace. This is necessary because we # don't have a "npm" workspace with the "@angular/bazel" NPM package installed. if replay_compiler_path != ctx.executable._ngc_wrapped.short_path: compiler = ctx.executable._internal_ngc_wrapped # END-INTERNAL else: fail("Unknown replay compiler", target.typescript.replay_params.compiler.path) ``` where as the npmjs.org file from https://registry.npmjs.org/@angular/bazel/-/bazel-8.2.13.tgz has a `tab` in place of the `#BEGIN-INTERNAL` to `#END-INTERNAL` ``` elif replay_compiler_name.startswith("ngc-wrapped"): compiler = ctx.executable._ngc_wrapped else: fail("Unknown replay compiler", target.typescript.replay_params.compiler.path) ``` It is this tab that the linter `buildifier_check` does not like. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Download the file from https://registry.npmjs.org/@angular/bazel/-/bazel-8.2.13.tgz to see the difference ## üî• Exception or Error I'm using this in a branch of the [ONOS](https://gerrit.onosproject.org/c/22800) project and I have `@angular/bazel` 8.2.13 in my `package.json` ``` scondon@Z420:~/onos$ bazel run //:buildifier_check INFO: Writing tracer profile to '/RaidData/scondon/.cache/bazel/_bazel_scondon/9eee44166e74bfc121cf827da25d905e/command.profile.gz' INFO: Analyzed target //:buildifier_check (43 packages loaded, 6897 targets configured). INFO: Found 1 target... Target //:buildifier_check up-to-date: bazel-bin/buildifier_check.bash INFO: Elapsed time: 9.911s, Critical Path: 1.11s INFO: 0 processes. INFO: Build completed successfully, 1 total action INFO: Build completed successfully, 1 total action ./web/gui2-fw-lib/node_modules/@angular/bazel/src/esm5.bzl # reformat ``` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 8.3.19
Node: 10.16.0
OS: linux x64
Angular: 8.2.14

Issues.Title: fix(service-worker): throw when using the unsupported `versionedFiles` option in config
Issues.Body:
In 5d5c94d, the deprecated `versionedFiles` option from the SW asset-group configuration in `ngsw-config.json`. As a result, the option would be silently ignored and the runtime behavior of the SW would change (i.e. some files might not be cached and available offline any more). This change could be easily go unnoticed by the developer.

This commit ensures this does not happen by throwing a build-time error, when detecting the unsupported `versionedFiles` option with an error message prompting the user to use the `files` option instead.

Jira issue: [FW-1727](https://angular-team.atlassian.net/browse/FW-1727)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(service-worker): throw when using the unsupported `versionedFiles` option in config" (#33903)

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): properly detect origin of constructor param types
Issues.Body:
The ReflectionHost supports enumeration of constructor parameters, and one
piece of information it returns describes the origin of the parameter's
type. Parameter types come in two flavors: local (the type is not imported
from anywhere) or non-local (the type comes via an import).

ngcc incorrectly classified all type parameters as 'local', because in the
source files that ngcc processes the type parameter is a real ts.Identifer.
However, that identifier may still have come from an import and thus might
be non-local.

This commit changes ngcc's ReflectionHost(s) to properly recognize and
report these non-local type references.

Fixes #33677
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): properly detect origin of constructor param types" (#33901)

Issues.Title: strictMetadataEmit causing unclear error message to occur during build
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package This appears to be a compiler issue so my guess would be @angular/compiler-cli ### Is this a regression? Not sure, I have never used this feature before ### Description I believe a specific compiler options called `strictMetadataEmit` is the problem. Either the error is displaying as a false positive, or this code is supposed to fail the build, but maybe a better error message is required. When using the CLI to create a new Angular Library like `ng new library`, the tsconfig.lib.json contains an `angularcompilerOptions` property called `strictMetadataEmit` that is set to `true` by default. When I try to build the following code, I get the error message: ``` ERROR in C:/Test/Test/application/src/app/app.module.ts:16:1: Error encountered in metadata generated for exported symbol 'AppModule': C:/Test/Test/application/src/app/app.module.ts:10:22: Metadata collected contains an error that will be reported at runtime: Lambda not supported. {"__symbolic":"error","message":"Lambda not supported","line":9,"character":21} ``` ``` import { JwtModule, JWT_OPTIONS } from '@auth0/angular-jwt'; export function jwtOptionsFactory() { return { // It believes there is a lambda here when this is clearly an anonymous function and is // completely valid JS, so I don't understand how it could be invalid. tokenGetter: function () { return null; } }; } @NgModule({ declarations: [ AppComponent ], imports: [ BrowserModule, JwtModule.forRoot({ jwtOptionsProvider: { provide: JWT_OPTIONS, useFactory: jwtOptionsFactory, deps: [] } }) ], providers: [], bootstrap: [AppComponent] }) export class AppModule { } ``` As soon as I do this, however, it builds just fine. ``` export function jwtOptionsFactory() { return { function tokenGetter () { return null; } tokenGetter: tokenGetter }; } ``` So it doesn't seem to be mad about a lambda, but rather a simple anonymous function, right? Am I missing some other lambda here or is the error mesage just a little unclear? ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Just pull this down and run `ng build`. The above code is my actual application code and doesn't reflect what is in this repository. https://github.com/mhintzke/angular-cli-aot-example ## üî• Exception or Error 

ERROR in C:/Test/Test/application/src/app/app.module.ts:16:1: Error encountered in metadata generated for exported symbol 'AppModule': 
 C:/Test/Test/application/src/app/app.module.ts:10:22: Metadata collected contains an error that will be reported at runtime: Lambda not supported.
  {"__symbolic":"error","message":"Lambda not supported","line":9,"character":21}

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): improve robustness of Node.js version check
Issues.Body: This change ensures that both the global version and the project version Node.js version requirements are met before the CLI executes a command.  Previously an older global version of the CLI would allow a newer project version to execute even if the project version had more strict Node.js version requirements.  The Node.js version is now checked twice.  Once in an ES5 safe script to ensure that ancient Node.js versions are not in use.  And secondly in the CLI entry code that is executed after global/project bootstrapping.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular/cli): improve robustness of Node.js version check" (#16218)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): mocked context in single test transform matches webpack API
Issues.Body:
I've ran into an issue at work with the mocked context in single test transform - it does not match [webpack API](https://webpack.js.org/guides/dependency-management/#requirecontext).

Basically I have to filter out certain values from `require.context(...).keys()` before importing the actual file to fix another issue in `test.ts`. (Desired outcome is for code coverage to include untested ts files)

Currently with angular 8 (and master branch) it fails when running `ng test --include <file>`, as the value returned from keys does not have a `filter` method. This PR fixes that by returning an empty array instead of partial object.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): mocked context in single test transform matches webpack API" (#16216)

Issues.Body:

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular/cli): update Intellij/Webstorm settings
Issues.Body:
Intellij and Webstorm unfortunately don't the use the exact same
configuration system. For example, Intellij treats every project as
`JAVA_MODULE` but Webstorm doesn't recognize the `JAVA_MODULE`.
Therefore, I think that the modules.xml and iml should be left
out from version control.

refs #16152

Issues.Title: Option to skip component styles for test build
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request

Provide a way to skip component style processing for unit test builds. 

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [x] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description

By far our biggest obstacle with Angular is atrocious testing performance. It is **incredibly** slow to build and run all our tests, and anything and everything that could be done to improve the situation would be welcome.

To that end, a flag to skip component style loading for test building would be very welcome. For unit testing, the contents of component styles are irrelevant, but the test build still appears to be running each component's `.scss` file through the style loader.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Add a new flag in `angular.json` build configuration called something like `noComponentStyles` that replaces the standard CLI style loader with a [null loader](https://webpack.js.org/loaders/null-loader/). 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Switching to React, as our Jest-based testing for React projects runs about 10x faster. I really can't emphasise enough how utterly poisonous the experience of testing is when we try to introduce developers used to other frameworks to our Angular projects.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Option to skip component styles for test build" (#16192)

Issues.Title: 9.0.0-rc.2: Dark theme issues
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

* Cannot reproduce on StackBlitz due to error. Sample code: https://components-issue-3aehwp.stackblitz.io

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create mat-tab-group/mat-tabs with labels, either via the 'label' attribute or using `<ng-template mat-tab-label>`
2. Apply a dark theme, e.g., `pink-bluegrey` or `purple-green`


 
#### Expected Behavior

The label (light color) should be displayed on the dark background.

#### Actual Behavior

The background is light (presumably white), and hence the label is not visible.


#### Environment

- Angular: 9.0.0-rc.2
- CDK/Material: 9.0.0-rc.2
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Ubuntu 18.04

![mat-tab-background-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28793852/69107678-673ccd00-0a2f-11ea-9df7-cd633bd94cc2.png)

Issues.Title: build: server-side rendering check not failing for async errors
Issues.Body: If an error is thrown asynchronously during server-side rendering (e.g. in rxjs subscription or a `setTimeout`), it'll be logged to the console but the script will still exit with 0. These changes add an `ErrorHandler` that'll rethrow the errors so that the CI fails properly.

Issues.Title: Mat-select lacks disabled (readonly) option
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a project
2. Add Angular material to the project
3. Create a form with fieldset in it and mat-select in it (form -> fieldset -> mat-select)
4. Add `[disabled]` to fieldset inside form tag to be `true` on submit
5. Force `disabled` to become true
6. Observe `mat-select` that user can interact with even though they should not
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Selector should be disabled.


#### Actual Behavior

It is not.


#### Additional info

I've read that `mat-select` has no `readonly` state because "native select doesn't have it", HOWEVER I want to point that when you make `fieldset` disabled the native selector disables and the user CANNOT modify value on form sumit. BUT when using Angular material user CAN change the value during submit even though it is inside `fieldset[disabled]`.

This makes it tricky to work with forms non-stop (for example when you can submit form, then form needs to be locked until it's submitted, after that you enable form and reset it's submitted state and let the user change/save the form again).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Mat-select lacks disabled (readonly) option" (#17743)

Issues.Title: refactor(ng-update): handle namespaced angular decorators in update-tool
Issues.Body:
Previously Angular did not support namespaced Angular decorators. e.g.

```ts
@core.Component({...})
@core.Directive({...})
```

Since this is now supported in ngtsc, we want to handle
such cases where stylesheets, templates are referenced in
namespaced decorators.

This can be achieved by moving the more advanced import
resolution logic made for the Hammer gesture migration
to the `cdk/update-tool`. Exposing these for other CDK
and Material migrations can be helpful anyway.

This also unveiled that we did not run non-misc test cases
automatically. This will be fixed as part of this commit.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(ng-update): handle namespaced angular decorators in update-tool" (#17737)

Issues.Title: test: clean up dom insertions in tests
Issues.Body: Fixes a few DOM insertion cases that I noticed while looking through some tests. E.g. in all the chips tests we were appending the element to the DOM ourselves and then removing it, even though Angular already inserted it in the DOM for us. Also fixes a few cases where we were inserting elements in tests, but not cleaning them up.

Issues.Title: build: Object.assign linting not working
Issues.Body: A long time ago we decided to ban uses of `Object.assign` because of some issues in g3, but the way we wrote it for the `ban` lint rule meant that it wouldn't be caught. These changes tweak the syntax and fix the cases that are being caught now.

Issues.Title: Mat-chip-list with required option always shows error
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use the chip list input example, add a formcontrol and a required input. (based on the [chip-list.spec.ts](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/chips/chip-list.spec.ts#L1453)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Prerequisite: Chip list with a form control and it is marked required. See this [Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-cfbb3w)
2. Focus on field
3. Focus out
4. Field is marked required in an error state
5. Add a new chip
6. Field is still marked required in an error state
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Field marked as Valid whenever there is a chip. Marked as Invalid and the error is shown when there are no chips in the list.


#### Actual Behavior

Once the field has lost focus, the error state is always shown, independently of the number of chips present.


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Chrome 78
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Mat-chip-list with required option always shows error" (#17742)

Issues.Title: build: add lint rule to avoid relative cross entry-point imports/exports
Issues.Body:
Adds a new lint rule to avoid relative cross entry-point imports
and exports. If a public entry-point imports from another entry-point
it should use the public module name in order to comply with the
Angular Package format, and to avoid unnecessary code inlining when
creating flat entry-point bundles.

Restructures the cdk testing fake-event code into `cdk/testing/testbed`
since that is where the fake event code is primarily used. This
makes the new lint rule happy, and also improves the public API
of `cdk/testing` since interfaces like `ElementDimensions` are
part of the `TestElement` class and should therefore be exported.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: add lint rule to avoid relative cross entry-point imports/exports" (#17741)

Issues.Title: Empty cdkList container "lose drop area" if its position changes.
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Hi, i've found some weird issue using a simple empty div as "drop container" in order to show users a box where to drop contents into.
It seems that if this box, for whatever reason, changes its visibility, position, etc... it loses the "drop capability".

Here's the stackblitz used to reproduce the bug:

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hqxu2m

Steps to reproduce:
1. Test the example dragging a "done" element into the "to do" list (a "exited" console log should appear each time you enter the "to do" container while dragging an element)
2. In the template file, uncomment the second line (as suggested by the comment) and retry the step 1, now it's impossibile to make the console log"exited" again
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The drop zone of the container should be always active


#### Actual Behavior

The drop zone of the container is lost whenever the container is moved around or it's visibility changes


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Chrome: 78.0.3904.97
- Operating System :  Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Empty cdkList container "lose drop area" if its position changes." (#17736)

Issues.Title: fix(sort): no focus indication for active header
Issues.Body:
Currently we rely on the arrow being toggled as focus indication in the sort header, but if the header is active, the arrow will always be visible so the user won't have a way of telling where focus is. These changes add an outline around the text for keyboard and programmatic focus.

Fixes #17716.

For reference:
![Angular_Material_-_Google_Chrome_2019-11-17_18-19-27](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/69011128-70fafd80-0967-11ea-8fa7-d0b62f1df9e3.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(sort): no focus indication for active header" (#17735)

Issues.Title: fix(datepicker): inconsistent focus restoration timing in touchUi mode
Issues.Body:
`MatDatepicker` has focus restoration which happens (almost) synchronously, whereas `MatDialog` restores focus asynchronously when the animation is finished. This means that in `touchUi` mode focus ends up being restored both by the datepicker and the dialog within a 150ms window. The problem is that if the consumer of `MatDatepicker` decides to move focus inside the `closed` event, it'll be ovewritten by the dialog 150ms later. These changes disable the dialog's focus restoration because it's unnecessary.

Fixes #17560.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(datepicker): inconsistent focus restoration timing in touchUi mode" (#17732)

Issues.Title: fix(portal): content not rendered inside outlet when view container is provided
Issues.Body:
Fixes the contents of the portal not being rendered inside of the `CdkPortalOutlet`  if an alternate `ViewContainerRef` is provided. We have some logic that moves the content into the outlet for `DomPortalOutlet` already, but we probably missed adding it to the directive since it isn't being used in as many places.

Fixes #17650.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(portal): content not rendered inside outlet when view container is provided" (#17731)

Issues.Title: Custom form field control don't need to provide MatFormFieldControl
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

I don't really understant the need to provide `MatFormFieldControl`. I've skimmed through the codebase without noticing any actual usage. No component/directive seems to inject the provided `MatFormFieldControl`.

AFAICT, it's just enough that the component implements `MatFormFieldControl` and `mat-form-field` should be able to get it with `@ContentChild`.

**Affected documentation page:** https://material.angular.io/guide/creating-a-custom-form-field-control#providing-our-component-as-a-matformfieldcontrol

Related issue: #16699
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Custom form field control don't need to provide MatFormFieldControl" (#17729)

Issues.Title: virtual-scroll Chrome makes images jump
Issues.Body:
I have a list of products and everything works fine on Safari and to some extend on Firefox. The list displays fine including some in line adds. https://tuganga-test-html.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com (use mobile tools.. on screen bigger than 768px there is no virtual-scroll implementation) The problem is with Chrome. Every product has a reference to an image: It looks like Chrome has problems calculating the height of the image before hand. Feels like it waits for the product to be inside de scroll window to create the
  • with the image. It is not fast enough and it gives the wrong image or jumps to a previous product. The problem can be mitigated making the scroll window's size, equals to the number of products * the hight of the product If I remove the image, scrolls woks fine. I have been working on a work around for a month. Please help #### Environment - Angular: 8.2.13 - CDK/Material: 7.2.0 - Browser(s): Chrome - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): all
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "virtual-scroll Chrome makes images jump" (#17728)

Issues.Title: fix(virtual-scroll-viewport): changeDetection run before translate scroll content.
Issues.Body:
Currently, reading some properties of the viewport element during the scroll (ngAfterViewChecked), can cause a scroll back.

this._contentWrapper.nativeElement.style.transform must be set before changeDetection.

Fix #17597
See [stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-ooljyt).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(virtual-scroll-viewport): changeDetection run before translate scroll content." (#17727)

Issues.Title: fix(bottom-sheet): don't move focus if it was moved during close animation
Issues.Body:
Currently we restore focus to the previously-focused element once the bottom sheet's exit animation has completed, however this can override any focus management the consumer might have done while the animation was running. These changes add extra check so that we only move focus if it was inside the bottom sheet at the end of the animation.

Along the same lines as #17300.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(bottom-sheet): don't move focus if it was moved during close animation" (#17725)

Issues.Title: Mouse scrolling freezes in weird edge cases
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-xy3jhe

Steps to reproduce:
1. Run the StackBlitz
2. Make sure the window is short enough to show vertical scrollbar
3. Start scrolling vertically by your mouse wheel, AND at the same time keep moving your mouse around the table (this is crucial - cannot reproduce with stationary mouse position)
 
Do note that if you do ANY of the following changes, the bug is no longer reproducible:
- modify *table-selection-example.ts* such that no checkbox is in selected state, eg. by changing the line
  ```ts
  selection = new SelectionModel<PeriodicElement>(true, ELEMENT_DATA.slice(0, 3));
  ```
  to
  ```ts
  selection = new SelectionModel<PeriodicElement>(true, ELEMENT_DATA.slice(0, 0));
  ```
- Remove from *table-selection-example.html*:
  ```html
  <mat-label>Search</mat-label>
  ```
  AND set `sticky: true` to `sticky: false` in:
  ```html
  <tr mat-header-row *matHeaderRowDef="displayedColumns; sticky: true"></tr>
  ```
 
#### Expected Behavior

The mouse wheel keeps scrolling the window without any interruption.

#### Actual Behavior

The mouse wheel can no longer scroll the window. You can scroll with keyboard arrows or by dragging the scrollbar by clicking on it. Hovering over `matTooltip` to display a Angular Material tooltip seems to fix the scrollbar and you can use the mouse wheel again, until it gets stuck again.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Google Chrome 78.0.3904.97
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): WIndows 10 v1903

Cannot reproduce the bug in Safari or Firefox on MacOS 10.15.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Mouse scrolling freezes in weird edge cases" (#17722)

Issues.Title: mat-table: change height of rows (mat-row) and cells (mat-cell) to 52px
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal: Change height of a row (`mat-row`)/cell (`mat-cell`) to 52px (51px + 1px bottom border) #### What is the expected behavior? [Material Designs Guidelines](https://material.io/components/data-tables/#specs) show the height of a row as 52px OR (51px + 1px top border) upon inspecting the code of the [material components for the web example](https://material-components.github.io/material-components-web-catalog/#/component/data-table) #### What is the current behavior? Currently, inside of `mat-table,` `mat-row` seems to show a height of 48px with no padding or border and `mat-cell` shows a height of 47px + 1px bottom border #### What are the steps to reproduce? Providing a StackBlitz reproduction is the *best* way to share your issue.
StackBlitz starter: https://stackblitz.com/angular/vjavnrpqeyj?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftable-basic-example.html
Open inspect element on any example of `mat-table` and find `mat-row` + `mat-cell` for an example. #### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior? Consistency across Material Design implementations. #### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected? All. #### Is there anything else we should know? N/A.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-table: change height of rows (mat-row) and cells (mat-cell) to 52px" (#17721)

Issues.Title: fix(ng-update): imports to `MatProgressSpinnerModule` not migrated
Issues.Body:
For v9 we generated a mapping of symbols and their corresponding secondary
entry-points. This map was based on the public API goldens we generate with
ts-api-guardian. Unfortunately ts-api-guardian has known limitations with
aliased exports which do not have the export keyword on the actual declaration.

This means that we currently do not have a mapping for such exports. Temporarily
changing ts-api-guardian to handle such cases showed that the progress-bar 
module is the only instance in the project.

Fixes #17715.

**Note**: This actually brings us to the point where we should re-consider the effort of switching to api-extractor from Microsoft eventually. This was already planned in the past, but we prioritized other things IIRC. The current API goldens are not guaranteed to be complete.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ng-update): imports to `MatProgressSpinnerModule` not migrated" (#17717)

Issues.Title: Revisit tool used for generating/validating API goldens
Issues.Body:
We should revisit our options for the API goldens. ts-api-guardian has known limitations with aliased symbol exports and standalone export statements.

At some point in the past, the tooling team thought about using `api-extractor` from Microsoft. We should explore this option. The api-extractor is already used in `@angular/bazel` too.

Related to #17717
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Revisit tool used for generating/validating API goldens" (#17718)
